titleStmt.title: First-Principles Study of a Full Cycle of Atomic Layer Deposition of SiO 2 Thin Films with Di(sec-butylamino)silane and Ozone

funder.orgName: Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities, China University of Geosciences
National Natural Science Foundation of China

analytic.title: First-Principles Study of a Full Cycle of Atomic Layer Deposition of SiO 2 Thin Films with Di(sec-butylamino)silane and Ozone

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents
application.label: 0.8.2-11-gf6b522b3f

startPage=-1, endPage=-1, consolidateCitations=0, consolidateHeader=0, consolidateFunders=0, includeRawAffiliations=false, includeRawCitations=false, includeRawCopyrights=false, generateTeiIds=false, generateTeiCoordinates=[], flavor=null

div.p: The energy landscape of a full atomic layer deposition cycle to grow a layer of SiO 2 on the hydroxylated SiO 2 (001) surface was systematically explored using density functional theory. A monoaminosilane-based compound, di(sec-butylamino)silane (DSBAS), was utilized as the silicon precursor with ozone acting as an oxidizing agent. The ALD cycle includes dissociative chemisorption of DSBAS, oxidation, and condensation for surface regeneration. Our results indicate that the dissociative chemisorption of DSBAS is kinetically facile. Upon oxidation by ozone, the layer grows with a SiO 2 crystalline morphology. The entire ALD cycle was found to be thermodynamically and kinetically favorable. This is important for growing dense and conformal SiO 2 thin films free of impurities and thus well-suited for low-temperature deposition of SiO 2 thin films.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: SiO 2 is one of the most important dielectric materials widely used in the microelectronics industry. Low-temperature deposition of SiO 2 thin films on semiconductor devices has been in increasing demand as the number of new applications rises rapidly and the feature sizes continue the trend of shrinkage. 1,2 High optical transmittance, chemical inertness, scratch resistance, and hardness are among the essential attributes of these thin films. 3 Conventional deposition techniques, such as chemical vapor deposition (CVD) 4,5 and plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD), [6][7][8][9] have long been developed for dielectric layer fabrications. Unfortunately, the step coverage limitation of CVD at high temperature is bottleneck for its application in the future, especially for depositing the patterned film structures with high aspect ratios. As a consequence, thin films deposited by CVD are no longer suited for nanosized nodes with very high-aspectratio structures due to their intrinsic shortcomings in thickness control, uniformity, and conformality. Although PECVD can produce SiO 2 films at a relatively low temperature (<300 °C), it is a notoriously poor process for step coverage as the substrate can be damaged by the use of plasma, and the produced surface impurities then become detrimental to the device performance. 10 With the continuous demand for smaller, more flexible but highly integrated devices in the electronics industry, the temperature range suitable for thin-film fabrications has become increasingly narrow. 11,12 Increasingly lower temperature deposition of SiO 2 thin films is required for development of a damage-free deposition process on patterned film structures or heat labile substrates with excellent device integrity and performance. [13][14][15] For the next generation of semiconductor devices, atomic layer deposition (ALD) techniques are widely accepted to be the preferred methods for depositing SiO 2 thin films at temperatures lower than 400 °C. 14,16 Thin films can be fabricated with precise thickness control, optimal large-area uniformity, and excellent conformality of the designated substrate topologies. 17,18 This process has been carried out by first site-selective deposition of a silicon precursor followed by surface oxidation to produce well-controlled SiO 2 layers. The quality of the SiO 2 films is largely dictated by the physicochemical properties of the selected precursors. Recently, several novel alkylaminosilanes-based precursors, 2,13,[19][20][21][22][23][24][25] such as bis(t-butylamino)silane (BTBAS) 2 0 ,2 4 and tris-(dimethylamino)silane (TDMAS), 21,26 have been studied as precursors for SiO 2 film deposition. For low-temperature SiO 2 film deposition, the performance of these precursors has been shown to be superior to silicon chloride based precursors with which an ALD process may lead to excessive particle formation and residual chlorine impurities in the fabricated films. 13 The alkylaminosilanes-based precursors first undergo a sequential dissociative chemisorption process on the hydroxylated SiO 2 surface, leaving a Si atom anchored on the surface as amines are released to the gas phase. Ozone or plasma-activated oxygen is then used to oxidize the surface intermediates to produce hydroxyl groups for subsequent deposition of the next layer.

The relative reactivity of precursor dissociative chemisorption is critical in determining the deposition temperature and the density, purity, and roughness of the thin films. A chemically active precursor allows the deposition to be carried out at a relatively low temperature. The precursor structure, to a large extent, is responsible for the quality of the films. 24 In the previous studies, 20,21 we investigated the dissociative chemisorption of TDMAS on the hydroxylated SiO 2 (001) surface and the ALD mechanisms of SiO 2 using BTBAS on the hydroxylated SiO 2 (001) surface. These precursors have been used for ALD processes of SiO 2 thin-film growth. It was found that a full ALD cycle using BTBAS is thermodynamically exothermic with moderate activation barriers. Given enough time to settle, the precursor will fully react with the substrate, leaving no impurities on the surface. This is in sharp contrast to the behavior of TDMAS in similar ALD processes, in which sequential dissociation can occur only up to the second step, resulting in an inherently low-density and compositionally impure SiO 2 film with a low deposition rate. The results demonstrate that aminosilane-based precursors for SiO 2 thin film fabrications should only allow up to two amino groups to be attached to the silane group in order to avoid deposition of surface impurities.

Here, we investigate the use of the monoaminosilane, di(secbutylamino)silane (DSBAS), for SiO 2 thin film deposition to develop a chemically more active precursor that may enable lower temperature deposition and a higher deposition rate. This molecule was proposed to be a promising precursor for lowtemperature silicon oxide film deposition. 27 In contrast to bis(aminosilane)-and tris(aminosilane)-based precursors, the monoaminosilane precursor containing only one amino group is expected to undergo more complete dissociative chemisorption. At the same time, the high chemical reactivity of monoaminosilane on surfaces may lead to a variety of structural arrangements upon completion of an ALD cycle. Understanding the detailed surface reaction mechanisms is thus essential for developing highly conformal, dense, and uniform SiO 2 thin films. In this paper, we present a theoretical study based on density functional theory, aiming to unveil the growth processes of a SiO 2 surface in a full ALD cycle with DSBAS as the precursor and ozone as the oxidizing agent. The reaction pathways leading to DSBAS dissociation, oxidation, and surface regeneration and the associated energetic properties are systematically investigated.

div.head: SURFACE MODEL AND COMPUTATIONAL
div.p: METHOD Normally, a deposition process starts with a SiO 2 surface fully hydroxylated, which facilitates the reaction of the substrate toward precursor molecules. In the present study, we focus on the growth of SiO 2 thin films via ALD on the fully hydroxylated SiO 2 (001) surface, which is the preferred orientation in amorphous silica. 28 The model of the reconstructed and fully hydroxylated SiO 2 (001) surface was obtained from our previous work (Figure 1). 20 A rectangular surface unit cell was selected with the optimized cell parameters of a = 17.02 Å and b = 14.74 Å. Between the slabs, an approximately 15 Å thick vacuum gap was inserted to avoid interactions between adjacent slabs. The supercell contained 24 Si atoms, 60 O atoms, and 24 H atoms. The surface was first equilibrated prior to precursor adsorption. The main calculated structural parameters were found to be in good agreement with the experimental values and previous DFT calculations. 28 All calculations were performed using density functional theory (DFT) with the exchange-correlation functional proposed by Perdew and Wang. 29 The projector augmented wave (PAW) method was used to describe the core electrons of atoms, and the valence orbitals were represented with a planewave basis set with a cutoff energy of 396 eV. Electronic energies were calculated using the spin-polarization scheme with a self-consistent-field (SCF) tolerance of 10 -4 eV. Structural optimizations were performed for all atoms of the initial-, intermediate-, and final-state structures, including the adsorbates but excluding the bottom three layers of the substrate, which were kept fixed, until the total energy of the system converged to within 10 -3 eV. Allowing the atoms of three of the bottom layers to relax resulted in only marginal changes in the surface structure with the differences in bond lengths and bond angles being less than 0.02 Å and 3°, respectively. The overall reaction was broken into a series of elementary processes, for each of which the transition-state structure was obtained using the nudged-elastic-band (NEB) method 30,31 to calculate the minimum-energy profile along the prescribed dissociation pathways with the initial and final states chosen based on the optimized structures and the number of images chosen to be six. The Brillouin zone integration was sampled within a 4 × 4 × 2 Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh, 32 and electron smearing was employed using the Methfessel-Paxton technique 33 with a width of 0.1 eV to minimize the errors in the Hellmann-Feynman forces. All calculations were performed with the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP). 34 For the analysis of atomic charges, we also employed the algorithm for Bader decomposition of charge density recently developed by Henkelman and co-workers. 35,36 The Bader charges quoted in this paper include both the core charge and the integrated electron density over the atomic basin. For purpose of comparison, DFT calculations using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof exchange-correlation functional 37 with longrange dispersion correction based on the Grimme's scheme 38 were performed for the dissociative chemisorption process of DSBAS (step a in Scheme 1). Only marginal changes in the optimized structures of the initial, transition, and final states were found. The differences in the calculated bond distances and bond angles are within 0.03 Å and 4°, respectively. Using the dispersion-corrected PBE functional, the reaction was found to be slightly less exothermic by 0.7 kcal/mol with the calculated reaction energy of -8.0 kcal/mol; the calculated activation barrier is 5.9 kcal/mol, slightly decreased from 6.1 kcal/mol obtained by using the PW91 functional. The reason to use PW91 in the current study is to facilitate consistent comparison with our previous work on the relative reactivity of different silicon precursors on the same surface. 20,21 Our results suggest that the chosen theoretical method and surface model are adequate.

div.head: RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
div.p: There are two types of hydroxyl groups: one is more exposed to precursor molecules (O1) and another is somewhat embedded (O2), as indicated in Figure 1, on the optimized SiO 2 (001) surface. The more exposed type was found previously to be more reactive than the embedded one. 21 The higher electron density on O1, coupled with the high surface exposure of the atom, makes the O1 sites more accessible for electrophilic attack by precursor molecules. The optimized DSBAS molecule is shown in Figure 2. Compared with BTBAS and TDMAS, there is only one amino group in DSBAS, making the Si atom less positively charged as expected. Indeed, as the number of amino groups bonded to the Si atom decreases, the lesser is the charge withdrawn from the Si atom. The calculated Bader charge on Si in DSBAS is 2.51 e versus 2.82 e in TDMAS and 2.68 e in BTBAS. In parallel, the N atom of DSBAS is negatively charged (-1.37 e), slightly smaller than that of TDMAS (-1.42 e) and BTBAS (-1.56 e).

Mechanistically, the ALD process with DSBAS on the SiO 2 (001) surface can be described in Scheme 1. The silicon precursor molecule first undergoes dissociative chemisorption on the hydroxylated SiO 2 (001) surface, resulting in the anchoring of the Si atom of the precursor on the surface and the release of amines into the gas phase. In contrast to the ALD process using BTBAS and TDMAS, a -SiH 3 intermediate species is formed on the surface via only one step of dissociative chemisorption of DSBAS since DSBAS is a monoaminosilane precursor. Subsequently, there are two possible reaction routes that lead to the formation of a new hydroxylated SiO 2 surface layer for the next reaction cycle. In route 1, the -SiH 3 intermediate species on the surface, formed from the dissociative chemisorption, reacts with a surface -OH group to form a -SiH 2 species by eliminating a H 2 molecule into the gas phase. Subsequently, ozone is introduced to oxidize the -SiH 2 intermediate on the surface to form -Si(OH) 2 groups. Alternatively, in route 2, the -SiH 3 species reacts with ozone immediately upon formation on the surface to form a -Si(OH) 3 group. The intermediate then reacts with a surface -OH group to form a -Si(OH) 2 group for the next ALD cycle. The reaction results in elimination of a water molecule from the surface.

3.1. DSBAS Dissociative Chemisorption. As shown in Scheme 1, step a, a DSBAS molecule on the hydroxylated SiO 2 (001) surface undergoes a one-step dissociative chemisorption process, leading to the formation of a -SiH 3 intermediate species on the surface and the elimination of a di(sec-butyl)amine (DSBA) molecule. The optimized structures of the initial, transition, and final states are shown in Figure 3, and the main structural parameters are presented in Table 1. In the initial state, DSBAS is adsorbed on the hydroxylated SiO 2 (001) surface through strong H-bonding between the N atom of the precursor and a surface H atom with the calculated adsorption energy of -6.7 kcal/mol, resulting in the elongation of the Si-N distance in DSBAS from 1.753 to 1.786 Å. Because the H atom at the O2 site is H-bonded to the O atom of the O1 type, the free H atom of the O1 site becomes more reactive to form a H-bond with DSBAS. The structural optimization yields a N-H distance of 1.836 Å for DSBAS, almost equivalent to that of BTBAS (1.854 Å) due to the similar electrostatic attraction and the steric repulsion between the bulky amine group and the surface.

As the DSBAS molecule comes into contact with the surface, the H atom of the O1-type OH group migrates to the N atom of the precursor, while the O1 atom simultaneously attacks the Si atom of the DSBAS molecule. Similar to the case in which BTBAS was used as the ALD precursor, this process undergoes a transition state with a loose Si-N bond in the precursor and a significantly elongated O-H bond on the surface. Here, a fourmembered ring is formed, leading to the partial dissociation of DSBAS. As the Si-N distance increases, the Si-O distance is decreased from 3.235 to 1.697 Å. Consequently, a -SiH 3 species is adsorbed on the hydroxylated SiO 2 (001) surface through a strong Si-O bond, and a DSBA molecule is released to the gas phase with the calculated desorption energy of 0.8 kcal/mol. Interestingly, as the H atom of the OH group is thermodynamically favorable, with the calculated surface reaction energy and overall reaction energy of -8.7 and -14.6 kcal/mol, respectively. The dissociative chemisorption of DSBAS is also kinetically facile with a relatively modest activation barrier of 6.1 kcal/mol. Only a small change in the surface geometry is necessary to accommodate the dissociative chemisorption of DSBAS. Another possible transition-state structure formed by a six-membered ring involving two OH surface species was also considered for the dissociative chemisorption of DSBAS. This process was found to be kinetically unfavorable with a substantially higher barrier of 44.9 kcal/mol due to the large separation between the two adjacent OH surface species and the requirement to transfer the H atom from the O2-type OH group to the O1 atom in the transitionstate structure.
3.2. Route 1: Reaction between the -SiH 3 Intermediate with the Surface -OH Group Followed by Oxidation.

To grow a denser and purer SiO 2 film via ALD, the -SiH 3 intermediate species on the surface could react with a surface -OH group to form a -SiH 2 group. There are three different types of surface -OH groups of O2 type in the proximity of the -SiH 3 intermediate as indicated in Figure 5. Therefore, the reaction may proceed along three reaction pathways. Mechanistically, the reactive processes are similar to each other with the Si atom of the -SiH 3 species attacking the negatively charged O atom of the surface -OH group, producing a surface -SiH 2 species and a H 2 molecule in the gas phase. However, different reaction pathways lead to different surface morphologies, which were examined via minimum-energy calculations.

First, the -SiH 3 intermediate species may react with an adjacent OH group (labeled "a" in Figure 5) to form an O-SiH 2 -O species to maintain its original surface orientation and allow the SiO 2 film to continue its crystalline growth. The optimized structures of the initial, transition, and final states are shown in Figure 6 (path a). The calculated main structural parameters are summarized in Table 2. Here, the Si atom of the -SiH 3 species attacks the O atom of the adjacent OH group, while the H a atom of the same OH group tilts toward the -SiH 3 species to form a H 2 molecule. This reaction undergoes a transition state involving a loose Si-H bond from -SiH 3 species and a significantly weakened O-H a bond on the surface. The calculated Si-O distance is 2.208 Å at the transition state, significantly longer than its equilibrium distance of 1.648 Å at the final state. A four-membered ring is formed, leading to the formation of a -SiH 2 species on the SiO 2 (001) surface and the release of a H 2 molecule. This reaction gives rise to only a slight relaxation in the surface geometry with the formation of hydrogen bonding around the -SiH 2 species. The optimized Si-O-Si and O-Si-O angles in the top surface layer are 153.6°and 106.3°, respectively, close to the corresponding values in SiO 2 single crystal (143.0°and 109.8°, respectively). The association of the Si atom with the adjacent OH group allows the film to grow with the (001)

surface orientation, which lowers the surface tension. Indeed, the calculated thermochemical energy of -18.0 kcal/mol indicates that the reaction is thermodynamically favorable. However, this process is kinetically unfavorable with the calculated activation energy of 36.8 kcal/mol. Structurally, the high activation barrier is mainly attributed to the long initial Si-O distance between the -SiH 3 species and the surface OH species.

Alternatively, the surface -SiH 3 species can also undergo a second route along which reaction occurs between the -SiH 3 species and the OH group (labeled "b" in Figure 5) that resides on the same substrate Si atom. The optimized structures of the initial, transition, and final states are shown in Figure 6 (path b). This bonding configuration represents a deviation from the (001) orientation of the SiO 2 substrate since the (001) crystalline surface requires the O atoms that form bonds with a Si atom come from closest neighboring Si atoms. As a consequence, this type of bonding network leads to the growth of a disordered SiO 2 film. The main optimized structural parameters are listed in Table 2. Similarly to the case of path a, the transition-state structure along path b (TS b ) consists of a four-membered ring with a Si-O distance of 1.736 Å, which is shorter than the analogous distance along path a (2.208 Å). This process may seemingly be easier than path a. However, the calculated activation barrier of 37.1 kcal/mol is slightly higher than the value of path a (36.8 kcal/mol). We note that after the reaction, a four-membered ring is formed with an unusually short Si-Si distance of 2.409 Å. As a consequence, the structure of the final product (P b ) exhibits a strong geometric strain with the O-Si-O angle of 88.5°, which deviates significantly from the typical angle of 109.8°expected for sp 3 hybridization. The highly stressed optimized structure indicates that the structure may not be as stable as the structure produced in path a (Figure 6b). Indeed, this process was found to be modestly endothermic with the reaction energy of 0.2 kcal/mol. It is interesting to note that despite the strong stress of the local bonding environment, only slight surface relaxation was found in the remaining part of the surface with the formation of hydrogen bonding around the -SiH 2 species.

In the third reaction pathway, the -SiH 3 species reacts with the neighboring surface OH group (labeled "c" in Figure 5) to grow a disordered SiO 2 film. The optimized structures of the initial, transition, and final states are shown in Figure 6 (path c). The main optimized structural parameters are displayed in Table 2. Compared with the transition state structures in path a and path b, the Si-O distance (2.607 Å) at the transition state is much longer, which arises from the longer Si-O distance (4.022 Å) in the initial state. This leads to a more unfavorable kinetic process for the elimination of H 2 molecule. Indeed, the calculated activation energy of path c is considerably higher than the values along the paths a and b (41.9 versus 36.8 and 37.1 kcal/mol), as shown in Figure 7. Thermodynamically, this process is moderately endothermic with the calculated reaction energy of 10.3 kcal/mol. The structure of the final product (P c ) exhibits a modest geometric strain with the O-Si-O angle of 117.1°, which deviates slightly from the typical angle of 109.8°e

xpected for sp 3 hybridization. The calculated Si-O distance is 1.679 Å in the final state, significantly longer than the corresponding values in SiO 2 single crystal (1.610 Å). Again, this reaction gives rise to only a slight relaxation in the surface geometry with the formation of hydrogen bonding around the -SiH 2 species.

We proceeded further to exam the oxidation reaction (step c in Scheme 1) with ozone to convert the surface -SiH 2 species to form -Si(OH) 2 groups for the subsequent reaction cycle, as shown in Scheme 1, step c. As expected, the reaction turns out to be highly favorable both thermodynamically and kinetically. The detailed results were published previously. 20 Here, we list only the main calculated data in Table 3. Our studies on the reaction suggest that the surface reaction between the -SiH 3 species and the adjacent surface hydroxyl group to eliminate H 2 is the rate-limiting step along the three minimum-energy pathways. However, none of the prescribed pathways is kinetically feasible for low-temperature deposition of SiO 2 films with an activation barrier of at least 36.8 kcal/mol. We thus conclude that kinetically it is highly difficult to eliminate a H 2 molecule upon anchoring a -SiH 3 species on the surface. The calculated structures of the initial, transition, and final states of the three sequential reaction steps are shown in Figure 8, and the main optimized bond parameters are listed in Table 4. In the first step (Figure 8a), both the Si-H bond and the O b -O c bond are slightly weakened as the O 3 molecule approaches the Si atom with a decreased Si-O c distance. A triangular structure is then formed at the transition state (O c -Si-H) to minimize the activation energy. At the final state, both the Si-H bond and the O b -O c bond become broken, leading to the formation of a -H 2 Si-OH species and the release of an O 2 molecule. We note that the ground electronic states of O 3 and O 2 are singlet and triplet, respectively. As the reaction proceeds, the ground state of the reactant (R1) changes from a singlet state to a triplet state of the product (P1). At the transition state, the O 2 molecule is not fully formed as it still maintains a significantly elongated bond with the O c atom. As a consequence, the ground electronic state of the transition structure remains to be singlet. As expected, the oxidation process is strongly exothermic with a thermochemical energy of 109.3 kcal/mol and a modest activation barrier of 12.7 kcal/mol (Figure 9).

A similar oxidation reaction with O 3 subsequently takes place to convert the second Si-H bond to form a -HSi(OH) 2 8b), the OH group on the Si atom formed from the first step forms a hydrogen bond with a neighboring surface -OH group with the calculated distance of 2.115 Å. The H-bonding effectively lowers the activation barrier by 0.9 kcal/mol compared to the value in the first oxidation step. The change of spin states from R2 to P2 via TS2 is the same as the case of the first oxidation step. Again, the process is strongly exothermic with the calculated thermochemical energy of 109.8 kcal/mol. The calculated activation energy of 11.8 kcal/mol is slightly lower than the value for the first oxidation step. The process to oxidize the third Si-H bond to form a -Si(OH) 3 group is virtually identical to the reactions discussed above. The optimized initial, transition state, and final structures are shown in Figure 8c. We note that the calculated Si-O c distance (3.230 Å) in the initial state is considerably longer than the values in step 1 and step 2 because the OH groups formed in the first two steps prevent the ozone molecule from getting closer to the target Si atom. Nevertheless, the formation of more hydrogen bonds leads to a slightly lower activation barrier of 10.5 kcal/mol than the corresponding values in the first two The reaction is strongly exothermic with the calculated thermochemical energy of -109.9 kcal/mol. Again, the ground electronic states of R3 and TS3 remain to be singlet, while the ground state of the final product P3 is triplet.

The calculated energy diagram for the entire oxidation process of the -SiH 3 species is displayed in Figure 9. Our results indicate that the reaction is inherently a facile process with highly exothermic thermochemical energies and modest activation barriers. Therefore, conversion from -SiH 3 into -Si(OH) 3 with ozone is expected to be rather complete at a relatively low temperature. In a previous study, 39 O 3 reaction with Si-H bonds on Si(001) surface was explored by Fink and Jenkins using molecular dynamics simulations. They proposed a different reaction mechanism in which ozone first abstracts a hydrogen atom to form a hydrotrioxy radical (HO 3

• ) followed by dissociation of the radical into a surface hydroxyl (-OH) species and a gas phase O 2 molecule. While this route may represent one of numerous possibilities of the reaction between the surface Si-H bonds and the O 3 molecules at finite temperature, both reaction routes suggest that the conversion from a Si-H bond to a Si-OH bond via oxidation by ozone is energetically favorable.

To recover the hydroxylated SiO 2 (001) surface for the next cycle of the ALD process, the -Si(OH) 3 species on the surface must undergo a condensation reaction with the adjacent surface -OH groups to eliminate water molecules from the surface. Similarly to the -SiH 3 intermediate species, there are three different types of surface -OH groups of O2 type in the proximity of the -Si(OH) 3 species, as indicated in Figure 10.

Consequently, the condensation reaction may occur along three pathways. As expected, regardless of which path, the reactive events turn out to be similar to each other with the Si atom of the -Si(OH) 3 species attacking the negatively charged O atom of the surface -OH groups. This results in formation of a surface -Si(OH) 2 species and elimination of a H 2 O molecule.

In the first path, the -Si(OH) 3 intermediate reacts with the adjacent O a H, which enables the film to grow along the original crystalline surface orientation (Figure 11 O bond in the -Si(OH) 3 species and a significantly elongated O a -H bond on the surface. Indeed, the calculated Si-O a distance of 1.860 Å at the transition state is considerably longer than its equilibrium distance of 1.628 Å at the final state. A four-membered ring structure is formed. This reaction gives rise to only a slight relaxation in the surface geometry with the formation of hydrogen bonding in the proximity of the -Si(OH) 2 species. At the final product state, the optimized Si-O-Si and O-Si-O angles in the top surface layer are 147.4°a nd 106.9°, respectively, very close to the corresponding values in the SiO 2 single-crystal structure (143.0°and 109.8°, respectively). The association of the Si atom with the adjacent OH group allows the film to grow with the (001) surface orientation, which lowers the surface tension. Indeed, the calculated thermochemical energy of -10.2 kcal/mol indicates that the reaction is thermodynamically favorable. Kinetically, this process is also more favorable than the reaction between the -SiH 3 species and a neighboring surface hydroxyl species, which eliminates a H 2 molecule from the surface. The calculated activation energy is 20.8 kcal/mol.

In the second path, the -Si(OH) 3 species undergoes a reaction with the surface -OH group residing on the same substrate Si atom, as depicted in Figure 11 (path b). This type of bonding network leads to the growth of a disordered SiO 2 film, since this bonding configuration represents a deviation from the (001) orientation of the SiO 2 substrate. The main optimized structural parameters are listed in Table 5. At the transition state, the distance of the Si-O b bond is 1.752 Å, slightly shorter than the analogous distance along path a (1.860 Å). Interestingly, a hydrogen bond with a length of 1.057 Å is formed between the H atom migrating from the surface OH group and its adjacent OH group in the transition state. The reaction gives rise to a four-membered ring in the product structure with an unusually short Si-Si distance of 2.624 Å. As a consequence, the structure of the final product (P b ) exhibits a strong geometric strain with the O-Si-O angle of 87.5°, which deviates significantly from the typical angle of 109.8°expected for sp 3 hybridization. The highly stressed optimized structure indicates that the structure (P b ) may be thermochemically unstable. Indeed, in contrast to path a, this process was found to be moderately endothermic with the reaction energy of 7.3 kcal/mol; the calculated activation barrier of 30.0 kcal/mol is also significantly higher than the value of path a. Despite the high geometric stress at the reaction site, only slight relaxation was found in the remaining part of the surface with the formation of hydrogen bonding around the -Si(OH) 2 species.

In the third pathway, a reaction between the -Si(OH) 3 species and the third hydroxyl group (-O c H) occurs to grow a disordered SiO 2 layer, as shown in Figure 11 (path c). The main optimized structural parameters are listed in Table 5. Compared with the case in path a and path b, the Si-O distance (4.123 Å) of the initial state structure is much longer, making the process kinetically more difficult. Indeed, the calculated activation energy of path c is the highest among the three paths considered (34.5 kcal/mol versus 20.8 kcal/mol for path a and 30.0 kcal/mol for path b), as shown in Figure 12. In addition, this process was found to be modestly endothermic with a reaction energy of 4.8 kcal/mol. The structure of the final product (P c ) exhibits a slight geometric strain with the O-Si-O angle of 117.7°, which deviates modestly from the optimal angle of 109.8°for an sp 3 configuration. The calculated Si-O distance of 1.678 Å at the final state is considerably longer than the corresponding values in the SiO 2 single-crystal structure (1.610 Å). Similar to the case in path a and path b, hydrogen bonding dictates the structure near the reactive site while surface relaxation is essentially marginal.

Combining the results of the extensive search for minimumenergy pathways that lead to the completion of a full ALD cycle for growing a SiO 2 layer on the SiO 2 (001) surface with DSBAS as the Si precursor and ozone as the oxidation agent, we show in Figure 13 the calculated energy diagram. It is clear that the ALD process is initiated by the dissociative chemisorption of DSBAS, which is both thermochemically and kinetically facile. Elimination of H 2 through reaction between the resultant -SiH 3 species and a nearby surface hydroxyl group is kinetically prohibitive. Thus, further reactions along this pathway can be essentially ruled out. The oxidation reaction with ozone converts the -SiH 3 species into a -Si(OH) 3 species. The sequential oxidation processes are highly exothermic with only moderate activation barriers as expected. Although there are three possible pathways for the -Si(OH) 3 species to react with the adjacent surface hydroxyl groups, only one of them is both thermodynamically and kinetically favorable, which leads to growing a SiO 2 thin film in a crystalline structure. This ensures the thin film deposited with DSBAS and ozone to be dense and conformal.

div.head: SUMMARY
div.p: An understanding of the detailed reaction mechanisms between precursors and the substrate is essential for growing dense and conformal SiO 2 thin films. In the present study, we employed density functional theory to systematically explore the energy landscape of a full ALD cycle to grow a layer of SiO 2 on the hydroxylated SiO 2 (001) surface using DSBAS as the precursor and ozone as the oxidizing agent. The ALD cycle was broken into a series of elementary processes, for each of which the surface structure and the associated thermodynamic and kinetic energies were calculated.

Our results indicate that the dissociative chemisorption of DSBAS is kinetically facile, with only a modest activation barrier of 6.1 kcal/mol, suggesting that DSBAS is a promising silicon precursor with strong chemical reactivity toward a hydroxyl species. This is potentially useful for design of a lowtemperature ALD process to fabricate SiO 2 thin films. We subsequently examined two possible reaction routes for the surface -SiH 3 intermediate species to further react with various surface species upon ozone oxidation. In the first route, the -SiH 3 species undergoes a reaction with a surface -OH group to produce a -SiH 2 species and eliminate a H 2 molecule from the surface followed by oxidation with ozone to yield a -Si(OH) 2 species. The first step for H 2 removal and -SiH 2 formation was found to be kinetically difficult with the calculated activation barrier of at least 36.8 kcal/mol, although oxidation with ozone is inherently facile. An alternative route, in which the -SiH 3 species is first oxidized by ozone followed by condensation to eliminate a water molecule from the surface, was then explored. The three sequential oxidation steps, which lead to formation of a -Si(OH) 3 species on the surface, are all highly exothermic with the calculated activation barriers lower than 12.7 kcal/mol. Subsequently, three possible pathways for the reaction between the -Si(OH) 3 species and the neighboring surface hydroxyl groups were investigated. The path that leads to the growth of the SiO 2 layer with the SiO 2 crystalline morphology was identified to be both thermodynamically and kinetically preferred. This is important for growing dense and conformal SiO 2 thin films. The entire ALD cycle was found to be highly exothermic largely due to the strong oxidation by ozone.

Compared with the two well-known silicon precursors, BTBAS and TDMAS, monoaminosaline-based precursors such as DSBAS display unique properties well-suited for SiO 2 thinfilm deposition. The chemical reactivity toward the surface hydroxyl groups is sufficiently high with favorable kinetics, partly due to the high exposure of the -SiH 3 functional group in the precursors. Once the -SiH 3 species is anchored on the surface, it should be chemically stable in an environment free of oxidizing agents. Upon oxidation, there is virtually only one reaction pathway which leads to the crystalline growth of a SiO 2 layer. As a consequence, the film is dense, conformal, and free of impurities.

div.p: Corresponding Authors *E-mail: hanbo@cug.edu.cn. *E-mail: chmch@nus.edu.sg

div.p: The authors declare no competing financial interest.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 1. Optimized structure of the hydroxylated SiO 2 (001) surface: (a) side view and (b) top view.

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 3. Optimized initial, transition, and final structures for the dissociative chemisorption of DSBAS on the hydroxylated SiO 2 (001) surface. The green balls represent the migrating H atom.

figure.head: Figure 4 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 4. Calculated potential energy profiles for the dissociative chemisorption of DSBAS.

figure.head: Figure 5 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 5. Three different types of surface -OH groups of O2 type in the proximity of the -SiH 3 .

figure.head: Figure 6 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 6. Optimized initial, transition, and final structures for the reaction between -SiH 3 species and surface -OH group: (a) path a, (b) path b, and (c) path c. The green balls represent the migrating H atom.

Route 2: Oxidation of -SiH 3 Followed by Water Elimination. An alternative reaction route relates to the conversion of the -SiH 3 intermediate into the -Si(OH) 3 surface species via oxidation by ozone, which subsequently undergoes a condensation reaction with the surface hydroxyl groups to eliminate water molecules. The oxidation process includes three sequential reaction steps, each of which turns out to be similar to each other with one O atom of the ozone molecule attacking the positively charged Si atom of the surface -SiH 3 species. The reaction leads to formation of a new surface Si-OH species and the elimination of an O 2 molecule from ozone.
